Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: To resolve a lawsuit brought by the California Attorney General, Heinz agreed to pay $600,000 and slash levels of the cancer-causing chemical acrylamide in its frozen french fries and tater tots.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/atty-gen-brown-settles-potato-chip-lawsuit-heinz-frito-lay-kettle-foods

Description: The CFTC announced that it had gotten a federal court to order Kraft and Mondelez to pay a total of $16 million in a case involving manipulation of the wheat market. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was split evenly between them. The press release about the case was removed from the CFTC website. Here we cite an archived version on the Nexis information service.
Info Source: Kraft and Mondelez Global to Pay $16 Million in Wheat Manipulation Case, Targeted News Service, August 15, 2019 (via Nexis).

Description: Kraft Foods agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle allegations it illegally dumped hot dog cases in ravines on a farm in Missouri, and also to end an ongoing legal dispute over tax credits and refunds the company received or claimed.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20021105222628/http://www.ago.state.mo.us/121901.htm

Description: Heinz Co. agreed to pay $180,000 in civil penalties and overfill its ketchup containers through California at an estimated cost of $651,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angeles and Shasta counties that it underfilled certain ketchup products.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20020221162913/http://da.co.la.ca.us/mr/2000/112900a.htm
